subject: Cybersecurity
title: Ports and Protocols: The Doors to Your Computer
description: A 60-second lesson on Ports and Protocols: The Doors to Your Computer.

hook.text: Your computer has 65,535 ports. Each one is a potential door. Attackers scan them all looking for one that's open.

buildup.text: Ports direct network traffic to specific services: HTTP on 80, HTTPS on 443, SSH on 22, DNS on 53.

discovery.text: Open ports are not inherently dangerous, but services running on them may have vulnerabilities attackers can exploit.

twist.text: The Mirai botnet scanned the internet for devices with port 23 (Telnet) open and default passwords â€” finding millions.

climax.text: Port management is basic hygiene: close what you don't need, patch what you keep open, monitor everything.

punchline.text: 65,535 doors. Attackers only need one left unlocked.

quiz.question: How did the Mirai botnet find vulnerable devices?
options: By scanning for devices with Telnet port 23 open and default passwords
